question_details.title: Will the following companies be added to the S&P 500 before 2026? (ARES)
question_details.description:
The [S\&P 500 Index](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%26P_500) is a stock market index that measures the stock performance of 500 large companies listed on stock exchanges in the United States. The index is maintained by [S\&P Dow Jones Indices](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S%26P_Dow_Jones_Indices), and inclusion decisions are based on factors such as market capitalization, liquidity, financial viability, and sector representation. Current index constituents can be viewed [here](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_S%26P_500_companies#S\&P_500_component_stocks).

S\&P 500 membership is valued by corporations because it indicates success and boosts brand awareness.

To join S\&P 500 a company must fulfill the following requirements:

* It must have a market capitalization of at least \$20.5 billion.
* It must be domiciled in the U.S.
* It must be a corporation whose shares are listed on an exchange, such as the New York Stock Exchange, the Nasdaq system, or one of the CBOE exchanges.
* It can not be a limited partnership, master limited partnership, closed-end fund, limited liability company, special purpose acquisition company, or SPAC.

Four possible candidates to be added to the S\&P 500 in over the following months are:

* [ARES (Ares Management Corporation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ares_Management): A global alternative investment firm specializing in credit, private equity, real estate, and infrastructure assets.
* [MSTR (MicroStrategy Incorporated)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/MicroStrategy): A business analytics company known for significant investments in Bitcoin as part of its corporate treasury strategy.
* [APP (AppLovin Corporation)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AppLovin): A mobile technology company providing software solutions for mobile app monetization, marketing automation, and in-app advertising optimization.
* [CVNA (Carvana Co.)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Carvana): An e-commerce platform for buying and selling used vehicles online, featuring direct-to-consumer delivery and a technology-driven customer experience.

question_details.resolution_criteria:
This question is a subquestion of a group question. This subquestion specifically targets the option 'ARES'. The resolution criteria for the parent question is below. 

Each subquestion will resolve as **Yes** if the corresponding company is announced to be officially added to the S\&P 500 Index before January 1, 2026, according to [S\&P Dow Jones Indices](https://www.spglobal.com/).
question_details.fine_print:
* Subquestions will resolve based on official announcements from S\&P Dow Jones Indices that a company will be added. The actual inclusion of the company to the index is not required for resolution.
* Potential retractions or cancellations of an inclusion announcement will not affect the resolution of subquestions.

**S&P 500's rejection of the company formerly called MicroStrategy may stop the crypto-acquisition frenzy: JPMorgan**
JPMorgan strategists, led by Nikolaos Panigirtzoglou, argue that the S&P 500’s decision to exclude the company formerly known as MicroStrategy—now Strategy MSTR—signals a broader concern about corporate treasury investments in cryptocurrency. The company meets the size and other key criteria for inclusion, yet its market capitalization is largely derived from bitcoin holdings rather than its underlying information‑technology business. The strategists claim the exclusion could limit the influx of crypto assets into investor portfolios and may prompt other index providers to reconsider including similar corporate crypto treasuries. They also note that the Nasdaq has begun requiring shareholder approval for companies that use crypto assets to fund new share issuances. The article suggests that investors and index providers might shift their focus toward crypto firms with real operating businesses, such as exchanges or miners, rather than corporate treasuries. 'This is signaling that the committee, which can apply discretion in its index inclusion decisions, is concerned about including in the S&P 500 index companies such as MicroStrategy that are effectively bitcoin funds,' the strategists said.

**S&P 500 changes are due out soon - and this could be a big update**
The S&P 500 index committee is expected to announce a quarterly rebalance after Friday’s close, with changes taking effect two weeks later.  The most recent quarter saw no updates, prompting speculation that the next reshuffle—typically the largest because it incorporates annual float‑factor adjustments—might bring new members.  Melissa Roberts, a managing director at Stephens, noted that the "third‑quarter reshuffle is typically the largest rebalance because it includes annual constituent float‑factor changes," and that "S&P Dow Jones Indices historically took advantage of the liquidity opportunity to make more discretionary changes than in other quarters."  To qualify for inclusion, a U.S.‑domiciled company must have a market capitalization of at least $22.7 billion, a float market capitalization of at least $10.25 billion, and demonstrate financial viability by being profitable on a GAAP basis in the most recent quarter and over the past four quarters.  Current candidates include AppLovin Corp. (APP), Reddit Inc. (RDDT), Pinterest Inc. (PINS), Robinhood Markets Inc. (HOOD), Sofi Technologies Inc. (SOFI) and Carvana Co. (CVNA).  AppLovin, with a $164 billion market cap, is the largest eligible firm, while Strategy Inc. (MSTR), formerly MicroStrategy, has newly cleared the financial‑viability hurdle.  Other newly eligible names are Astera Labs Inc. (ALAB) and Pure Storage Inc. (PSTG), the latter having risen 42 % in the last month.  Although Robinhood was expected to join, it was not selected in the last rebalance and remains the third‑largest eligible company not yet in the index.  Roberts suggests a fintech addition may be less likely this time, noting recent inclusions of Interactive Brokers Group Inc. (IBKR), Block Inc. (XYZ) and Coinbase Global Inc. (COIN).

**MicroStrategy’s Bitcoin Empire Rises, Sizing Up for S&P 500 Inclusion**
MicroStrategy, led by Michael Saylor, has built a Bitcoin‑backed empire that is now a serious candidate for inclusion in the S&P 500.  The company’s unrealized gains of $14 billion in the last quarter theoretically satisfy the index’s profitability requirement.  If accepted, passive funds tracking the index would be forced to buy roughly 50 million shares, worth about $16 billion at current prices, according to Stephens analysis.  MicroStrategy’s market cap of $22.7 billion and its high liquidity ratio place it ahead of other potential candidates such as AppLovin, Robinhood and Carvana.  The S&P committee also considers industry balance, and the recent addition of Coinbase Global Inc. and Block Inc. signals growing acceptance of digital‑asset companies.  Saylor’s strategy of raising debt and equity to purchase Bitcoin has drawn skepticism, especially after the company’s stock fell 17 % in August and its 30‑day volatility reached 96 %, higher than Nvidia’s 77 % and Tesla’s 74 %.  Despite these risks, MicroStrategy’s inclusion could trigger the so‑called "index effect" and attract passive inflows from large institutional investors.  Saylor has publicly suggested 2025 could be the year the company joins the S&P 500.  "纳入Coinbase是他们欲拓展该行业群体的强烈信号，" Stephens’ managing director Melissa Roberts said, highlighting the committee’s focus on industry representation.  The S&P spokesperson declined to comment beyond the index methodology, noting that committee discretion remains a key factor.

**Company MSTR Meets Requirements for Inclusion in S&P 500 Index, Decision Expected Friday**
MicroStrategy (MSTR), now trading under the name Strategy, has officially qualified for possible inclusion in the S&P 500 index after reporting its best quarter ever.  As of June 30, the company held 597,325 BTC, and the Bitcoin‑yield since the start of the year was 19.7 %, a key performance indicator that measures the change in the ratio of BTC held to the diluted number of shares.  In Q2 2025, Strategy reported operating income of $14 billion and net profit of $10 billion, translating to $32.6 earnings per diluted share (EPS).  Quarterly revenue was $114.5 million, a 2.7 % year‑over‑year increase, while subscription‑service revenue rose almost 70 %.  The shift to fair‑value accounting in January 2025 allowed the firm to recognize unrealised gains on its digital‑asset holdings, directly boosting profitability.  Management has raised its 2025 outlook to $34 billion operating income, $24 billion net profit and $80 EPS, assuming Bitcoin ends the year at $150,000.  With a market cap well above the $8.2 billion threshold, daily trading volume over 250,000 shares, more than 50 % free float, and positive earnings for the last quarter and the trailing twelve months, Strategy meets all S&P 500 eligibility criteria.  The next potential inclusion window is the September 2025 rebalancing, with announcements expected on September 5 and effective changes on September 19.  If added, Strategy would be the first Bitcoin‑reserve‑holding company to enter the benchmark index, marking a significant milestone for digital‑asset integration into U.S. equities.

summary:
Forecasters generally agree that Ares Management Corporation (ARES) is a strong candidate for S&P 500 inclusion before the end of 2025. All experts highlight that ARES surpasses the required eligibility criteria with a robust market capitalization significantly above the $20.5B threshold, solid GAAP profitability, consistent financial viability, high liquidity, and ample public float. Importantly, forecasters repeatedly point out that ARES operates in the financials/alternative asset management sector, which is underrepresented in the current S&P 500, creating a strong rationale for its addition according to both market structure needs and sector-rebalancing trends.

Across various financial, accounting, and economics perspectives, analysts note that recent S&P 500 committee behavior demonstrates both openness to adding large, stable, sector-diversifying companies and an unpredictable discretionary element—some qualified companies (notably MicroStrategy and Robinhood, in earlier cycles) have been passed over despite technical eligibility. This element is identified as the principal risk to ARES’s inclusion, in tandem with competition from other eligible large-caps (e.g., AppLovin, Robinhood, Carvana, Cheniere Energy), and the finite number of rebalance windows remaining (likely just one, in December 2025). The absence of negative news, controversies, or unusual business model risks for ARES strengthens its case.

Final probability estimates provided by the experts range from a low of 38% to a high of 75%. Most cluster in the moderately high range (55–75%), with many assigning around 65–68% probability, reflecting a belief that ARES is more likely than not to be added, but acknowledging significant uncertainty due to discretionary committee decisions and ongoing competition for limited index openings. Specific scenarios for a 'No' outcome center on the committee prioritizing additions from other sectors (notably technology or energy), minimal index turnover, or unexpected negative developments for ARES. 'Yes' scenario consensus involves ARES being chosen to boost financial sector weighting, its high eligibility, and available openings from M&A or index deletions. Overall, the expert consensus is moderately optimistic (above a coin flip) that ARES will be announced as added to the S&P 500 before January 1, 2026, principally due to its sector fit, eligibility, and analyst consensus, but with meaningful caveats regarding committee discretion and competition.
